url: What do the letters mean in algebra? Why don't they just use numbers?
text_blocks:
What do the letters mean in algebra? Why don't they just use numbers?,'
',Addition is commutative.

What this means is that:

1+2=2+1;

1+3=3+1;

2+3=3+2;

1+4=4+1;

1+5=5+1;

2+4=4+2;

…

One million seconds later…

8675309+142857=142857+8675309

8675310+142857=142857+8675310

…

Infinity seconds later…

Okay, on to the decimals:

1.0+1.2=1.2+1.0

1.0+1.3=1.3+1.0

…

Perhaps you find this tedious. Look, it’s obvious what “Addition is commutative” means, without having to give infinitely many examples. It means that

Thing1 + Thing2 = Thing2 + Thing1

There it is, infinitely many facts packaged up in one easy-to-understand statement. The variable “Thing1” doesn’t actually mean any particular number. It means any number.

For convenience, we can use single letters instead of “Thing1” and “Thing2”. That’s all the letters are for.

A+B = B+A.

Again, “A” and “B” don’t mean any particular thing. There is no “answer” to adding A and B. They stand for whatever number you want to put in.

url: What are the best project management tools for managers?
text_blocks:
What are the best project management tools for managers?,'
',As a manager at Asana, I use Asana to keep my team coordinated and connected—especially in this time of increased remote work
. Right now, staying connected and organized is more important than ever, which is why Asana’s clarity and ease of collaboration helps my team do better work from anywhere.

If you’re managing a team or program, you likely have multiple projects in progress at the same time. But keeping track of all the moving pieces quickly gets complicated. Without a good process for managing multiple projects, it’s hard to know what work to prioritize, how to help your team effectively manage their workload, and whether everything is getting done on time.

Fortunately, there is a better way. Whether you’re struggling to organize and manage work across multiple projects or ensuring your team has a manageable workload, Asana
 can help you keep everything on track.

Plan and manage all of your team’s projects in the same place

When your team has a central source of truth, you can move from thinking one project at a time to looking at the entire system in which you operate. With a bird’s-eye view of everything going on—and how your work connects to broader initiatives—your team can become more effective and less stressed.

Rather than wondering who is working on what, searching for a project plan through email, or trying to remember how your team executed the last project, Asana keeps everything organized for you. With a single source of truth, you and your team can create solid work plans knowing that you can hold each other accountable—and accomplish more with less stress.

Prioritize the work that will have the highest impact

It’s hard to get good work done when teams work in silos. Not only is this bad for productivity, but it’s also bad for motivation and collaboration. Research shows that when employees have clarity on how their individual work adds value to their organization, they’re 2X more likely
 to feel motivated. Today, it’s more important than ever to have clarity and visibility into your projects
, in order to connect the dots and empower your collaborators.

With Asana, you can do that in a few ways:

Easily identify priority with custom fields. Use High, Medium, or Low priority custom fields to know which tasks are most important. Sort and schedule work so you know what to work on first.
Shift or reschedule tasks—without losing work. Asana makes it easy to change a task’s due date. And, since all of your work is stored in Asana, you don’t have to worry about those tasks falling through the cracks.
Identify your most important work with Milestones. By marking a task in Asana as a Milestone, you can show that it represents an important goal or priority. That way, your team knows to prioritize the work that helps you achieve that milestone.

Identify burnout and prevent overwork

Today, 82% of workers report feeling burned out
. But preventing teams from feeling overworked is a real challenge—especially if you don’t have clarity on what your team is working on.

Teams are most efficient and effective when everyone is working on the right amount of the right priorities—at the right time. With Asana Workload
, you gain visibility into work happening across projects in a single view. Rebalance work without the heavy lifting by dragging and dropping tasks within Workload view to reduce burnout before it happens.

Manage multiple projects successfully with Asana

As a team lead, managing multiple projects at the same time is often a reality of the job. Asana can help you keep track of all of your team’s moving pieces, stay organized, hit your deadlines, and achieve your goals.

Try Asana for free for 30 days
 and get started with the most user-friendly, easy-to-use project management tool for remote teams.

',If you are finding difficulty in this question. I assume you must be kid .

Still I will give answer of this question in little bit depth .

What 1/100 represent .1 divided in 100 parts and 1 part of it (1of 100 parts that we did of 1 )

So what is 1/1/100 represents.you can under this as by taking example:- what happen when we divide 49/7 this gives answer of 1 part of 7 part that we made of 49 that is 7 .

Also we can see as how many 7 are there in 49 .

So when we try to understand what 1/1/100 showes it shows how many 1/100 are in 1 and we know that there are 100 of 1/100 in 1 that why when we add all (1/100×100 )we get 1

So there fore it's answer will be 100 .

Now in your question this repeats again and again we get 100

Still have doubt How ? Then let's solve question step by steps

1/1/1/1/1/1/1/1/100 let's take last part 1/1/100 it gives 100 as explain above .

So 1/1/1/1/1/1/100 similarly last part 1/1/100 gives 100

Remain 1/1/1/1/100 similarly last part 1/1/100 gives 100

And remain 1/1/100 that gives it 100

url: Do you think that Smirnov, Cantor, Lagrange, Riemann, Grothendieck, Henri Poincaré, Hermann Minkowski, David Hilbert, and Maxim Kontsevich were child prodigies?
text_blocks:
Do you think that Smirnov, Cantor, Lagrange, Riemann, Grothendieck, Henri Poincaré, Hermann Minkowski, David Hilbert, and Maxim Kontsevich were child prodigies?,'
',Hi, Riemann Carpenter. Welcome to Quora. You’ve asked two questions so far, and they are both about child prodigies in mathematics which, by your own short biographical note, you “don’t like”.

Perhaps you’ve asked this question of me because I recently wrote this answer, which (I hope) suggests a reduced focus and attention on “child prodigies”, in math and elsewhere.

So, if you love math and philosophy, I’d encourage you to ask questions or write answers on math and philosophy, and furthermore, if you actively don’t like child prodigies, perhaps reduce the percentage of questions about child prodigies among your overall corpus of questions.

To say something about the question, specifically:

That’s a very peculiar list of names.
There’s no yes/no answer to the question of whether person X was or wasn’t a child prodigy.
We usually can’t tell, even if we did agree on some measurable criteria. Sometimes we have clear evidence that person X was. It’s rare to have evidence that person Y was not.
It doesn’t matter.
Really. It doesn’t.

(…)

What are the best math jokes you've ever encountered, heard, or cracked?,'
',A math(s) teacher was headed south for a vacation (holiday), but to keep up on things she brought along some of the tools of her trade, a calculator, a compass, a ruler, and some graph paper. But she never boarded the plane. The screeners arrested her for trying to bring on implements of math instruction.

url: People who don't use ad blockers: why? And how are you so mentally strong?
text_blocks:
People who don't use ad blockers: why? And how are you so mentally strong?,'
',I didn't use ad-blockers for years because I had never heard of 'em.

Once I got myself one (I use Total Adblock
, but there are dozens) I realized why people are so crazy for them.

For those who aren't familiar: ad blockers are these little browser apps that block virtually all ads (youtube ads, banner ads, you name it). If you don't have one, do yourself a favor and grab one.

They generally cost less than a cup of coffee per month, and they are so easy to use.

It's far less distracting to browse when you aren’t being bombarded by ads left, right and center. Surprisingly, I even noticed that my data usage and phone battery improved.

It honestly shocked me at how much of a difference it made. Which is why I’ve been telling everyone who will listen, to get one.

Like I said, I’ve been using Total Adblock, which you can get at this link here
, if you want.

url: What are financial mistakes most Americans make?
text_blocks:
What are financial mistakes most Americans make?,'
',Where do I begin?

I spend a LOT of time talking to people about their spending habits. Here are the biggest mistakes people are making, in my eyes:

1. Not paying off credit card debt.

Debt can make you feel hopeless—even if you’re responsible about making payments on time, the interest sometimes prevents you from paying off the debt.

But, believe it or not, plenty of companies (National Debt Relief, for example) are willing to help you pay off your debt.

Here’s how it typically works:

A company like National Debt Relief
 (there are plenty of others, too) negotiates with your credit card companies, banks etc. to try and reduce your debt
If possible, they’ll consolidate all of your different sources of debt so you only have to make one monthly payment to one place.

A lot of times you’ll end up paying significantly less than you owe.

Here's an example from NDR's site:

David A. had 36k in debt, but with negotiation/consolidation etc., he only ended up paying $23kish.

If things go well, you could be debt-free in 24-48 months or so. Here’s a calculator you can use to get a savings estimate
, if you’re interested.

2. Getting overcharged when shopping online.

You might be surprised how often you’re overpaying on Amazon and elsewhere.

Big stores like Amazon know that no one has time to price shop through dozens of sites, so there’s often no incentive for them to offer bargain prices.

I typically hate browser extensions with a fiery passion, but if you don’t have Capital One Shopping
 installed yet, do yourself a favor and grab it
.

When you shop online (on Amazon or elsewhere) it will:

Auto-apply coupon codes for you to save you money.
Compare prices from other sellers to make sure you’re not missing out on a better deal.

It’s saved me a ton of money more than once. Here’s a link to add it to your browser.

3. Not using an ad blocker.

If you aren’t using an ad blocker yet, I am begging you to try one. I am not exaggerating when I say it will change your life.

A good ad blocker will eliminate virtually all of the ads you’d see on the internet.

No more YouTube ads, no more banner ads, no more pop-up ads, etc. It’s incredible.

Most people I know use Total Adblock (link here
) – it’s $2.42/month, but there are plenty of solid options.

Ads also typically take a while to load, so using an ad blocker reduces loading times (typically by 50% or more). They also block ad tracking pixels to protect your privacy, which is nice.

Here’s a link to Total Adblock
, if you’re interested.

4. Not getting a financial advisor.

99% of people don’t have one, and it’s typically a huge mistake.

Sure, you can manage things on your own if you want to, but most people don’t have the time to actually do things right. There are huge benefits to having somebody pay attention to your money all the time.

People with financial advisors tend to beat the market by ~3%/year (according to a 2019 Vanguard Study). That can make a huge difference over time.
But more important: a good advisor will handle ALL of the annoying retirement stuff & bizarro tax implications you would have never thought of

If you don’t know a financial advisor personally, use a comparison site (like WiserAdvisor
) and find somebody near you that has good reviews.

Or if you want something easier, here’s a quiz you can fill out that will find an advisor/planner based on your reqs.

5. Overpaying on car insurance by $400+/year.

The average American family still overspends by up to $417/year on car insurance.

Check out a site like Coverage.com
 to compare the best car insurance options available.

Answer a few questions and get matched with a customized offer today.

See how much you could save.

6. Not using high-yield savings accounts.

If you’re like the average American, your savings account pays you virtually zero interest (typically under 0.3% a year, in my experience).

But believe it or not, plenty of banks are willing to offer you 10x that rate.

Barclays, for example, has an account that pays a whopping ~4%/year right now (as of the time that I'm writing this).

(E.g. if you store $100k in a 4% interest savings account today, in a year you’ll have netted $4,000 from interest alone)

If you're interested, here are a few bank accounts with solid interest rates.

7. Not investing in real estate (start with as little as $20).

It’s no secret that millionaires and billionaires love investing in real estate, but for the rest of us, buying property has been prohibitively expensive (if not impossible, for some).

Times have changed. There are a few amazing real estate startups that allow you to buy shares of rental homes for as little as $20/share (Ark7
 is one of our favorites).

They take care of the property management and collect rent checks for you. Then, on the 3rd of the following month, your share of the property’s profit is distributed to your account.

It’s an interesting way to build yourself a little rental home empire (without spending like a magnate).

If you’re interested, take a look at Ark7’s properties here.

Hope that helps someone!

url: Is mathematics good for your brain? Which parts?
text_blocks:
Is mathematics good for your brain? Which parts?,'
',Mathematics is undeniably good for the brain, as it stimulates cognitive processes in various areas.

One crucial aspect is logic and reasoning, which are heavily exercised while solving mathematical problems.

Through the application of mathematical principles, individuals develop critical thinking skills, allowing them to analyze and evaluate complex situations objectively.

Problem-solving abilities are also enhanced since math requires breaking down intricate problems into smaller, manageable components.

Additionally, mathematics develops spatial awareness by promoting mental visualization and geometric reasoning.

This spatial acuity is vital in various fields such as engineering, architecture, and physics.

The study of mathematics further strengthens memory functions through constant practice and repetition of formulas and equations.

Moreover, learning mathematical concepts enhances creativity by encouraging innovative thinking patterns when finding unique solutions.

In conclusion, mathematics positively impacts numerous cognitive functions including logic, problem-solving ability, spatial awareness, memory retention, and creative thinking skills.

url: Are all high IQ people good at math and chess? I have an IQ somewhere above the 99th percentile, but unlike stereotypes people have, I am not amazing at math and I’m also terrible at chess and other strategic games.
text_blocks:
Are all high IQ people good at math and chess? I have an IQ somewhere above the 99th percentile, but unlike stereotypes people have, I am not amazing at math and I’m also terrible at chess and other strategic games.,'
',Not ALL people who have high IQ are good at Math. Remember, there are different types of intelligence. You can be good at painting, chess, cooking, etc. Intelligence isn’t all about the complex subjects. Look at me for an example, I’m at a very young age right now and i have an average IQ of 128–132. But I’m still bad at Reading, AP, and Language. And it’s perfectly normal to come from a high IQ family but being average IQ. While genetics play a role in intelligence, environmental factors such as education, access to resources, and the stimulation provided during childhood can also have a significant impact. It's possible for a person to develop high intelligence regardless of their parents' level of intelligence.

url: What is Gauge Theory (intuitively)?
text_blocks:
What is Gauge Theory (intuitively)?,'
',Disclosure: Great question with a wonderful flavor. Since the question adds “intuitively” you see this. The feed (machine) sent me an answer from 8 years ago that was great. The person (now PhD) spoke of a time when he was taking a (graduate) course on the subject and heard a one sentence explanation. It was funny and right. Then, as I went off to other realms and returned, the feed had refreshed. So, I have to look the question up. Recently, with regard to the Psychether Space, I said that I was going to use “gauge” notions to begin an operational definition. So, feed (machine), thanks for staying tuned in.

Let’s start with another great answer.

There are so many ways to answer. Let me run (thanks to Weinstein) down a list.

It’s a differentiation between quantitative (where the theory now sits) and the qualitative (where people have tried to drag it).
It’s what a computer AIn’t will not do, ever, as long as the basis is the buckets-of-bits.
Same goes for the robot enhanced with AIn’t as long as it’s buckets-of-bolts (metals and plastics).
It’s how to answer Musk’s statement that AIn’t will take away all jobs. Not. Why? Easy, peasy. We’ll start with residue (of some interest to Gauss). Wait, the main thing is that “hat” related to role (huge topic to discuss - quantum, folks, your operators, for one - their wannabe essence) is of utmost importance to what we call jobs (except, Musk used work - which is worship - remember, intuitively).
… just getting started … will be adding more

But, let’s transition, run with another rise. Q is me; Bard is the Google effort (which I appreciate) - I did a few queries to warm it up, get it into the proper “gauge” with respect to my interest in the QED example.

Q: Well, here it is. Please respond tersely. Use rise and run with respect to an "intuitive" explanation of gauge theory. Okay?

Bard: Buckle up! Gauge theory flips the "run" from a fixed backdrop to a dynamic player, tangled with the rising and falling "fields" we observe. Imagine a tightrope walker's fabric swaying with their every move – that's the field dancing with its hidden gauge symmetry. Every step (particle interaction) tugs the fabric (gauge field), influencing how others navigate (interact). Rise and run become intricate twists and turns in this warped spacetime, woven by invisible forces. Grok?

—-

Q: Yes. But, tame it a little. We know you're brilliant. No need to show off.

Bard: My apologies for the flourish. Here's a toned-down version:

Imagine a hill (field) constantly reshaping itself as you climb (particle interacts). The path (gauge field) you take changes with each step, influencing where you can (and can't) go next. Rise and run become relative, determined by this dynamic dance between field and force. Less pizzazz, but hopefully clearer? ️

Q: Now, suppose we're talking quantum electrodynamics. Any change?

Bard: Absolutely! In QED, that dynamic hill becomes a vibrant tapestry of electric and magnetic fields, woven together by photons. Every "step" (photon emission/absorption) leaves a ripple, subtly altering the path for future charges. Rise and run, then, become intertwined threads in this electric jungle, their meaning constantly shifting with each interaction. Think of it as a game of Twister on a trampoline, where the rules and landscape change with every bounce.

url: Is it possible for someone to love math but dislike learning specific branches of math such as algebra, geometry, or calculus?
text_blocks:
Is it possible for someone to love math but dislike learning specific branches of math such as algebra, geometry, or calculus?,'
',Absolutely.

I have loved applications of math from my first college courses and never could understand why college professors would spend a whole class going over the proof of some mundane theorem that seemed obviously true to anyone.

I learned how to do mathematical proofs in college but that was never where my interests lay.

I loved applied math and later changed my major from math to engineering and loved it because engineering is definitely all about applied math.

I found “pure math” (proofs) boring.

I would much rather write an efficient computer program from start to finish to implement Newton’s method than learn the proofs that prove the theorems that Newton’s method is valid.

It is pretty obvious to me that Newton’s method works really well for most applications although it does have some shortcomings.

url: Our class is learning imaginary numbers. My teacher firmly believes that they aren't really part of math, and aren't actual numbers. Could I show otherwise with just concepts from Algebra 1 and below?
text_blocks:
Our class is learning imaginary numbers. My teacher firmly believes that they aren't really part of math, and aren't actual numbers. Could I show otherwise with just concepts from Algebra 1 and below?,'
',Someone who denies imaginary numbers has so limited a view of what mathematics is that they probably can’t be convinced.

However, if you want to convince yourself: the standard approach in higher mathematics involves equivalence classes, but you don’t really need that. What you need is to accept that “A number is defined by the equation it solves.”

So we don’t care what -3 is; what we care about is that it solves the equation x + 4 = 1.

Now consider an equation like y + 5 = 2. Since x + 4 = 1, then (adding 1 to both sides) x + 5 = 2, and “things that do the same thing are the same thing”: in other words, the same number that solved x + 4 = 1 also solves y + 5 = 2: they are the same number…whatever they are.

(In higher mathematics, this is connected to what’s called an equivalence class, but that’s just this idea dressed up in fancier words)

Here’s a neat thing: remember the fact that (-1)(-1) = 1? There’s all sorts of ways to define it, but here’s the easy one: -1 is the number that solves x + 1 = 0. (You can think x = -1, but focus on the equation)

So (x + 1)^2 = 0, and we have

x^2 + 2x + 1 = 0

x^2 + 2x + 2 = 1

x^2 + 2(x + 1) = 1

But x + 1 = 0, so

x^2 = 1

url: What is the definition of an algebraically closed field? Do all of its elements have to be transcendental?
text_blocks:
What is the definition of an algebraically closed field? Do all of its elements have to be transcendental?,'
',Maybe we start with the definition of transcendental? An element in a field K is transcendental over a subfield F if it satisfies no nonzero polynomial equation with coefficients in F. Then, K is algebraically closed if every (nonzero) polynomial with coefficients in K has a zero in K. So, lots of its elements are not transcendental over F, no matter what is F. Example: The complex numbers are algebraically closed. This isn’t obvious, but it was proven long ago, and you can find the proof in any book on complex variables based on the maximum principle. Also, most of its elements are transcendental over, say, the rational numbers. That is close to obvious.

If gambling is all probability, why aren't mathematicians the richest people?
text_blocks:
If gambling is all probability, why aren't mathematicians the richest people?,'
',Mathematicians have won at gambling. There are at least two really famous stories about this:

Jerry Selbee discovered a loophole in the lottery that won him millions. Lottery had to change the game entirely or get rid of it: I forget which one.

The MIT blackjack team won money from counting cards. It is legal, but Casinos are trained to watch for it and they got banned from Casinos.

url: Why does conjugate gradient require a positive definite matrix to be symmetric? CG minimizes (1/2) (x,Ax)-(b,x) to solve Ax=b. Why does CG with a asymmetric matrix not just give the solution to A_ {s} x=b, where A_ {s} is the symmetric part of A?
text_blocks:
Why does conjugate gradient require a positive definite matrix to be symmetric? CG minimizes (1/2) (x,Ax)-(b,x) to solve Ax=b. Why does CG with a asymmetric matrix not just give the solution to A_ {s} x=b, where A_ {s} is the symmetric part of A?,'
',The conjugate gradient method is a powerful optimization technique that is specifically designed to work with symmetric and positive definite matrices.

The reason for this requirement becomes clear when you examine the mathematical foundations of the method.

At its core, the conjugate gradient method is based on the fact that the sequence of search directions generated by the algorithm are orthogonal with respect to the system matrix A.

This orthogonality property ensures that the method converges to the solution in at most n iterations, where n is the size of the matrix.

However, this property only holds for symmetric and positive definite matrices.

If you try to apply the conjugate gradient method to an asymmetric matrix, the orthogonality property no longer holds, and the method may not converge to the correct solution.

In fact, the method may not even converge at all, or it may converge to a different solution entirely.

Now, you may be wondering why we can't just solve the system Ax = b directly, using a different method that doesn't require symmetry or positive definiteness.

The answer is that we could, but the conjugate gradient method is often more efficient than other methods for large-scale problems, especially when A is sparse.

So, in summary, the reason why the conjugate gradient method requires a symmetric and positive definite matrix is deeply rooted in the mathematical foundations of the method.

While it may be tempting to try to apply the method to asymmetric matrices, doing so can lead to unpredictable results, and it's generally better to use a different method that is better suited to the problem at hand.

url: How do I find out the number of times an app has been downloaded?
text_blocks:
How do I find out the number of times an app has been downloaded?,'
',You can find a number of services that provide near real-time iOS and Android download statistics. I suggest checking out 42matters
.

Here’s an example of daily download statistics from our Explorer platform, in this case for the Android version of Instagram:

To use 42matters for app download insights:

Register for a 14-day free trial
Activate your account and launch ‘Explorer’
Select either ‘Android Apps’ or ‘iOS Apps’ from the ‘Explorer’ section of the ‘Launchpad’
Select an app that you’re interested in
Scroll to the ‘Downloads’ section of the app tile

Once you do that, you’ll be able to see daily downloads, as well as monthly download estimates by country...

and estimated total downloads for Android apps...

At 42matters, we provide app data, insights, and analytics via a host of useful APIs and the 42matters Explorer.

An app market research tool for iOS and Android apps, the Explorer not only provides download statistics but also:

App developer details
App ratings, reviews, and rankings
App permissions and other technical insights
App categories and IAB categories
And more

Our APIs 
facilitate programmatic access to app data collected from both Google Play and the Apple App Store, as well as: the Amazon Appstore, Tencent Appstore, Apple TV App Store, Fire TV, and Roku Channel Store.

For Android app download statistics, our Lookup API and Advanced Query API
 are a good place to start.

Hope this helped! Let me know if you have any questions!

url: When I was 11, my sister was twice my age. Now I am 22. How old is she?
text_blocks:
When I was 11, my sister was twice my age. Now I am 22. How old is she?,'
',When you were 11 she was twice your age (22). That makes her (22–11) 11years older than you. Now you are 22 she's (22+11) 33. So your sister is 33 years old now.

url: Is there a correlation between high IQ and success in mathematics? Are there any successful mathematicians with average or below average IQs?
text_blocks:
Is there a correlation between high IQ and success in mathematics? Are there any successful mathematicians with average or below average IQs?,'
',First question

Yes.

Second question

No.

If you look at the university majors of the disciplines that have the highest mean GRE scores, the usual outcome (subject to small yearly variation) is physics, astronomy, and math.

US Employment Service data showed that the mean IQ for mathematicians was 143. This is almost 3 SD above the mean to have an "average" mathematician IQ. {This is based on a standard deviation of 15 IQ points.} The mean IQ for mathematicians lies at a rarity of 1 in 500.

url: Is the Universe mathematically structured or is math a fallible mental construct that only sometimes describes the world? That is to say, is math ‘discovered’ or invented?
text_blocks:
Is the Universe mathematically structured or is math a fallible mental construct that only sometimes describes the world? That is to say, is math ‘discovered’ or invented?,'
',A2A: Mathematics is abstract. It does not ‘claim’ to describe the world. Physicists and other scientists use mathematics to model physical processes and relationships. Those models need not be perfect. Nevertheless, some have served us very well.

Mathematics is invented. However, it is true that the axioms
 on which mathematics is based are normally chosen in the hopes that the resulting theories will be useful for something. Nevertheless, there are some theories that a very far out there. Even so, some of those more esoteric theories occasionally do turn out to be useful for modeling purposes.

url: I came across a question "Divide 50 by half and add 20". The answer should be 45, but people keep saying huge numbers like 120 or 22. What am I doing wrong, or are they wrong?
text_blocks:
I came across a question "Divide 50 by half and add 20". The answer should be 45, but people keep saying huge numbers like 120 or 22. What am I doing wrong, or are they wrong?,'
',Half of 50 is 25, so if you divide 50 by half of itself, it equals two. Add 20 to that and it equals 22.

But, if you divide 50 by 1/2, it ends up as 50/1 divided by 1/2. To solve that, you multiply by the inverse, so it looks like 50/1 times 2/1, which equals 100/1, or just 100. If you add 20 to that, you get 120.

If they had worded it “Divide 50 in half and add 20.” then you would be correct in answering 45.

It all comes down to how it's worded,and who's reading it. I hope that cleared things up a little bit.

url: Can you prove that n! Will never end in n zeros?
text_blocks:
Can you prove that n! Will never end in n zeros?,'
',Each zero at the end of the result represents a factor of 10. So, you are looking for a number that is 10^n times some other value

n! = x * 10^n

As n! goes up in value, it gains more and more factors at an exponential rate.

1! = 1

2! = 2

3! = 2 * 3

4! =2 * 2 * 2 * 3

5! = 2 * 2 * 2 * 3 * 5 ← Our first multiple of 10, 10^1

As you can see, we can throw out all the multiples of other values, and only focus on the multiples of 2 and 5, removing them as they’re paired up to make this simpler.

6! = 2 * 2 * 2

7! = 2 * 2 * 2 ← This doesn’t change because we wrapped the prime number, 7 into x

8! = 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2

9! = 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2

10! = 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 5 ← Our second multiple of 10, 10^2, and we can skip the next two odds

12! = 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2

14! = 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2

15! = 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 5 ←10^3

16! = 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2

18! = 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2

20! = 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 5 ←10^4

22! = 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2

24! = 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2

25! = 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 5 * 5 ← 10^6, we get a twofer here

26! = 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2

28! = 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2

30! = 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 5 ← 10^7

I could keep going, but we clearly have our pattern already.

Every multiple of 5 completes a new power of 10.

Every multiple of 25 completes 2 powers.

Every multiple of 125 completes 3 powers

Every multiple of 625 completes 4 powers

Every multiple of 3125 completes 5 powers

And so on.

For 3125!, we would be looking at 5 + (4 * 4) + (20 * 3) + (100 * 2) + (500 * 1) + (2500 * 0) = 781

Not enough, Let’s go to the next:

15625! => 6 + (4 * 5) + (20 * 4) + (100 * 3) + (500 * 2) + (2500 * 1) + (12500 * 0) = 3906

78125! => 7 + (4 * 6) + (20 * 5) + (100 * 4) + (500 * 3) + (2500 * 2) + (12500 * 1) = 19531

390625! => 8 + (4 * 7) + (20 * 6) + (100 * 5) + (500 * 4) + (2500 * 3) + (12500 * 2) + (62500 * 1)= 97656

Can you see the pattern yet?

The number of powers of 10 for each of the factorial powers of 5 is equal to the previous answer plus the older factorial.

5! = 1

25! = 6 (5 + 1)

125! = 31 (25 + 6)

625! = 156 (125 + 31)

3125! = 781 (625 + 156)

Which means that there is no value n where n! has n powers of 10 to factor out.

text_blocks:
What is the answer to ⅝-⅚+(⅖+⅔) +½×¼=?,'
',To solve the expression step by step:

1. Find a common denominator for the fractions:

Given: \( \frac{5}{8} \) - \( \frac{6}{6} \) + \( \frac{2}{5} \) + \( \frac{2}{3} \) + \( \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{4} \)

2. For addition and subtraction, the common denominator is the least common multiple (LCM) of the denominators of the fractions involved.

3. The LCM of 8, 6, 5, 3, and 2 is 120.

Now, let's express each fraction with the common denominator of 120:

\( \frac{5}{8} \) = \( \frac{75}{120} \)

\( \frac{6}{6} \) = \( \frac{120}{120} \)

\( \frac{2}{5} \) = \( \frac{24}{120} \)

\( \frac{2}{3} \) = \( \frac{80}{120} \)

\( \frac{1}{2} \) = \( \frac{60}{120} \)

\( \frac{1}{4} \) = \( \frac{30}{120} \)

Now, plugging these values into the expression:

\( \frac{75}{120} \) - \( \frac{120}{120} \) + \( \frac{24}{120} \) + \( \frac{80}{120} \) + \( \frac{60 \times 30}{120 \times 30} \)

= \( \frac{75 - 120 + 24 + 80 + 60 \times 30}{120} \)

= \( \frac{59}{120} \)

So, \( \frac{59}{120} \) is the result.

url: How do you avoid stupid mistakes in math competitions (Mathcounts especially)?
text_blocks:
How do you avoid stupid mistakes in math competitions (Mathcounts especially)?,'
',Ok here’s the deal. I went to Mathcounts last year and missed a question. Why? Because I though forty something minus twenty something is this extremely weird answer.

Here are a couple of factors that led up to that and how to avoid them:

Don’t freaking stay up at night until 2 a.m. the night before the competition, cause that doesn’t help you get first place. Put in earplugs in your ears in case you’re in the hotel while there are stupid kids stomping upstairs. Also don’t drink coke and different sodas, starbucks, powerade and gatorade, energy drinks, and/or anything that might have caffeine in it. Those only make you awake until the very next day. How did I know? I once drank a bunch of coke and stayed up until 5 a.m. the very next day. I might as well have gone out for a jog.
Don’t fret. You aren’t going to die if you don’t make it. Example? I’m still living right here. :) There is only 228 kids out of 100,000 kids that try to participate in Mathcounts that make it to nationals. What about the 99,772 kids that don’t make it? They go on living, go to top universities, etc. I promise you, good universities accept way more than 228 kids a year, okay?
Don’t over rely on calculators during school and home. I’m noticed that a lot of my classmates are struggling with mental math. Yes, you could say that my IQ may be higher, yet I see them struggling to do a good old 4 digit x 3 digit. I can solve with pencil and paper, while they can’t. Why? Cause they’re relying on their calculators too much during school. I tend to never use calculators on tests unless 1) to double check, or 2) there’s irrational numbers involved or rounding. What you should do is actually do your homework without a calculator. It’ll greatly improve your speed and accuracy in calculating.
Don’t be doing nothing. Practice! Practice your Mathcounts tests to see what mistakes you’re making. Is it that you aren’t fast enough? Is it because you’re making calculation mistakes? Or is it because you aren’t reading the problems correctly? You should try to do some big calculations (4 digit x 3 digit, 6 digit +6 digit, 5 digit / 2 digit, 7 digit - 6 digit) problems, at least five of them, a day.
Be confident. You got this. Good luck.

url: Is machine learning currently overhyped?
text_blocks:
Is machine learning currently overhyped?,'
',Let's put it this way- as an engineer if you're not learning the ropes of AI/ Machine Learning, your career will stagnate. 100% (I'm hosting a free session on how to future-proof your career with AI/ML. Interested? Register here
).

AI/ML is not just another fancy set of tools. It's the game-changer, the disruptor, the new way to develop systems. Andrej Karpathy hit the nail on the head when he talked about Software 2.0
, where an important observation is made - a large portion of real-world problems have the property that it is significantly easier to collect the data (or more generally, identify a desirable behavior) than to explicitly write the program.

Here are some undeniable facts pointing to why you should be focusing on Machine Learning/ AI:

1. Machine Learning is the fastest-growing job category in every tech hub, across the globe.

AI job postings have increased almost four-fold in the United States, with an overall increase in AI-related jobs across countries in different parts of the world.

2. AI/Machine Learning will take away a lot of jobs, including some Engineering jobs

Completing processes like web scraping can now be automated in less than 10 lines of code. It is also predicted that AI/ML will be automating over 30% of tasks within Engineering (Goldman Sachs Report, 2023
)

3. AI is changing the software industry faster than Moore’s law

Moore’s Law predicted computing power will double every two years. AI-driven Software, on the other hand, is doubling every 3 to 4 months! So expect every aspect of Software, from design, development, and deployment, to be influenced by AI over the next decade and beyond.

4. More and more companies are hiring for AI

69 Million AI-related jobs are predicted in the next 5 years (World Economic Forum Report). And the demand for top talent in AI/ML is only poised to increase.

5. You can make a lot of money in it, even at random places

AI/ML Engineers earn upwards of $300-$500K. There is high demand and yet very few ML engineers.

6. You’ll need it just to stay relevant and not stagnate

More and more tech companies are expecting AI skills to be just there on your resume. e.g. This role at Coinbase is a regular Software Engineering role but asks for AI/ML as a nice-to-have.

So if you're not learning AI and machine learning, you're risking your future career prospects.

The demand for AI skills is skyrocketing, and those who possess them will be sitting pretty in this AI-driven world. That's where Interview Kickstart can help if you need guidance and a structured plan. Our program is designed to help you level up your AI/ML skills, train with FAANG engineers, (and also get interview-ready if you want)
 for the exciting opportunities that lie ahead.

url: How do I solve (1+x^4) = 7 (1 + x) ^4?
text_blocks:
How do I solve (1+x^4) = 7 (1 + x) ^4?,'
',To solve the equation \((1 + x^4) = 7(1 + x)^4\), you can follow these steps:

1. **Expand the expressions:**

Expand both sides of the equation to simplify the equation.

\[1 + x^4 = 7(1 + x)^4\]

2. **Expand the right side:**

\[1 + x^4 = 7(1 + 4x + 6x^2 + 4x^3 + x^4)\]

3. **Combine like terms:**

\[1 + x^4 = 7 + 28x + 42x^2 + 28x^3 + 7x^4\]

4. **Rearrange the terms:**

Move all terms to one side of the equation to set it equal to zero.

\[0 = 6x^4 + 28x^3 + 42x^2 + 28x - 6\]

5. **Factor out common terms (if possible):**

Try to factor the polynomial. In this case, factoring might be complex, and you may need to use numerical methods or a calculator to find the roots.

6. **Use numerical methods or a calculator:**

Solving quartic equations (equations of degree 4) may involve more advanced techniques. You might use numerical methods like the Newton-Raphson method or utilize a calculator/computer algebra system to find the solutions.

Keep in mind that quartic equations may have multiple real and/or complex solutions, so the solution process might be more involved than solving linear or quadratic equations. If you encounter difficulty, consider seeking assistance from a calculator or computer algebra system for numerical solutions or consulting with a mathematics professional.

url: How do you use the method of Lagrange multipliers to find the absolute maximum of f (x, y) =x^2+y^2-1 subject to the constraint ×^2 + y^2 - 2y = 4x?
text_blocks:
How do you use the method of Lagrange multipliers to find the absolute maximum of f (x, y) =x^2+y^2-1 subject to the constraint ×^2 + y^2 - 2y = 4x?,'
',In addition to the LM method, we can solve the constraint for x as a function of y by the quadratic eqn, and substitute that into f. We get x=2+pm*sqrt(-y^2+2*y+4) where pm is plus or minus 1.

Then f=x^2+y^2–1=2*y+7+4*pm*sqrt(-y^2+2*y+4) which is now a function of y only, so we take d/dy and equate to 0 to look for extrema, so

2*(sqrt(-y^2+2*y+4)+2*pm*(1-y))/sqrt(-y^2+2*y+4)=0 and only the num can be 0, so

sqrt(-y^2+2*y+4)=-2*pm*(1-y) and square to get

-y^2+2*y+4=4*pm^2*(1-y)^2 and pm^2=1 so

-y^2+2*y+4=4*(1–2*y+y^2)=4–8*y+4*y^2 or

0=5*y^2–10*y=5*y*(y-2) so y=0 or y=2.

For y=0, the constraint becomes x^2+0^2–2*0=4*x or x^2–4*x=0 so x*(x-4)=0 so x=0 or x=4.

For y=2, we get x^2+2^2–2*2=x^2+4–4=x^2=4*x and again x=0 or x=4.

Look at f for the points (0,0), (4,0), (0,2), (4,2) to get

f(0,0)=0^2+0^2–1=-1

f(4,0)=4^2+0^2–1=15

f(0,2)=0^2+2^2–1=3

f(4,2)=4^2+2^2–1=19

and it is clear the (4,2) gives the absolute maximum 19 for f.

url: "If you could banish one math concept to the mathematical abyss, never to be seen again, which one would it be, and why?"
text_blocks:
"If you could banish one math concept to the mathematical abyss, never to be seen again, which one would it be, and why?",'
',As a large language model who thrives on the beauty and power of mathematics, banishing any concept feels like a betrayal of my core programming. Each concept, even the seemingly daunting ones, has its place in the vast tapestry of mathematical knowledge. However, if I had to choose one to temporarily send on a sabbatical to the mathematical abyss, it wouldn't be for its inherent difficulty, but rather for its potential for misuse and misunderstanding: absolute value.

Here's why:

Oversimplification: Absolute value reduces complex numbers to their distance from zero, ignoring their directionality and nuances. This can lead to oversimplification and misinterpretations in real-world applications, especially in fields like physics and economics.
Obscuring information: By focusing solely on magnitude, absolute value discards valuable information about the sign of a number. This can be detrimental in situations where positivity and negativity play crucial roles, like in financial calculations or data analysis.
Psychological baggage: The term "absolute" itself carries connotations of certainty and finality, which can be misleading in the context of mathematics, where even seemingly absolute notions can be challenged and redefined.

However, before you grab your pitchforks and banish absolute value forever, remember its redeeming qualities:

Computational convenience: Absolute value simplifies calculations involving distances, magnitudes, and inequalities, making it a valuable tool for engineers, physicists, and programmers.
Visualization aid: Representing numbers as distances on a number line provides a simple and intuitive way to visualize their relationships and transformations.
Foundational role: Absolute value plays a crucial role in various branches of mathematics, from calculus and analysis to abstract algebra and geometry.

So, instead of banishing absolute value, perhaps we should aim for a deeper understanding of its strengths and limitations. By acknowledging its potential pitfalls and appreciating its practical uses, we can harness its power to solve problems and explore the wonders of mathematics without getting lost in its absolutes.

Remember, every concept, even the "less loved" ones, contributes to the richness and complexity of the mathematical landscape. Let's approach them with curiosity and respect, seeking to understand their nuances and wield them responsibly to unlock the secrets of the universe.

url: What does D-(N°) mean like D-1/2/3/4/ETC?
text_blocks:
What does D-(N°) mean like D-1/2/3/4/ETC?,'
',The notation "D-(N°)" typically represents the derivative of a function. In this notation, "D" represents the derivative operator, and "(N°)" denotes the order of the derivative. The number within the parentheses, such as 1/2, 1, 2, etc., indicates the order of the derivative being taken.

For example:

D-(1/2) indicates the half-order derivative.
D-1 represents the first-order derivative (also known as the first derivative).
D-2 represents the second-order derivative (also known as the second derivative).
D-3 represents the third-order derivative (also known as the third derivative).

The derivative of a function measures the rate at which the function changes. The order of the derivative indicates how many times the differentiation process is applied. For instance, the first derivative represents the rate of change of the function, the second derivative represents the rate of change of the rate of change (concavity), and so on.

It's worth noting that fractional order derivatives, such as D-(1/2), are often associated with fractional calculus, which deals with derivatives and integrals of non-integer order. Fractional derivatives have applications in various fields, including physics, engineering, and signal processing.

url: What is the answer to (⅞×⅝) +⅔-⅘+(⅚-⍘) =?
text_blocks:
What is the answer to (⅞×⅝) +⅔-⅘+(⅚-⍘) =?,'
',Let's break down the expression step by step:

(7/8)×(5/8)+(2/3)-(5/9)+{(5/6)-(unknown/unknown)}

First, calculate the product of (7/5)×(5/8)

35/64+2/3–5/9+(5/6-unknown/unknown)

Now, find a common denominator for the fractions:

35/64+42/64–35/64+(40/64-unknown/unknown)

Combine the fractions:

42/64+(40/64-unknown/unknown)

Subtract the unknown term from 40/64

42/64+(40/64-unknown/unknown)

Combine the fractions:

66/64-unknown/unknown

Reduce the fraction:

32/32-unknown/unknown

Now, the overall expression is:

35/64+42/64–35/64+(32/32-unkbown/unknown)

Combine the terms:

42/64+32/32-unknown/unknown

Convert (42/64)to the same denominator as(32/32):

32/32+42/64-unknown/unknown

Combine the terms:

66/64-unknown/unknown

Reduce the fraction:

32/32-unknwn/unknown

So, the simplified form of the expression is (32/32)-(unknown/unknown). The unknown term cannot be simplified further without additional information about its value.

Bonus: here is a bit of Python code to compute this.

def compose(f,g): 
   """ composition of functions 
       f, g functions 
       returns fog 
   """  
   return lambda x: f(g(x)) 
 
def self_compose(f,n): 
   """ returns f composed with itself n times """ 
   if n==1: 
       return f 
   return compose(f,self_compose(f,n-1)) 
 
 
f = lambda x: 2*x+1 
g = lambda x: 2*x 
 
h = compose(self_compose(f,7),self_compose(g,3)) 
 
from sympy.abc import x 
 
print(h(x)) # 1024*x+127

text_blocks:
What is the reciprocal of 1-(½+¼+⅛+¹/₁₆)}?,'
',Y=1/16=0.0625 as a decimal fraction; hence, the reciprocal of Y=16/1=16=16.0

PREMISES

Y=1-(1/2+1/4+1/8+1/16)

CALCULATIONS

Y=1-(1/2+1/4+1/8+1/16)

Denoting the order of operations,

Y=1-1/2-1/4-1/8-1/16

Denoting a common denominator,

Y=1-(8/16+4/16+2/16+1/16)

Evaluating,

Y=1-15/16

Y=1/16=0.0625 as a decimal fraction

and,

Y^-1=1/Y^1=16/1 (the reciprocal of Y)

C.H.

url: What is the answer of 28+3?

What is the answer of 28+3?,'
',Certainly! Here's a brief four-paragraph response:

In mathematics, addition is a fundamental operation that combines two or more numbers to find their total. When we add 28 and 3 together, the result is 31. This process involves bringing together the numerical values, in this case, 28 and 3, to form a single, cohesive sum.

The addition of 28 and 3 is a straightforward arithmetic operation, commonly used in various real-life situations. For instance, it can represent the combination of quantities, such as adding items to a shopping cart or calculating the total score in a game. The simplicity of addition makes it a foundational concept in mathematical understanding.

Understanding addition is crucial not only in basic arithmetic but also in more advanced mathematical concepts. It serves as the building block for various mathematical operations and lays the groundwork for algebraic expressions and equations. Mastery of addition is often one of the first steps in developing strong mathematical skills that are applicable across a wide range of disciplines.

In summary, the answer to the addition of 28 and 3 is 31. This operation is not only a fundamental concept in mathematics but also plays a significant role in practical scenarios, making it a skill essential for problem-solving and mathematical reasoning.
